I was absolutely killing it today. "Get these back to me by 5, Mel." Ms. Calliope had written. 5? More like 50 minutes later, which nicely rounded out to 2:15. I was on fire! That meant... Hmm, what did that mean?

I huffed and puffed off the couch (the new one had finally arrived- oh, how wide the delivery guy's eyes had gone when I threw myself on the new plated-steel framed sofa!) and it was definitely... "cushier" than our old one. I think it was pretty low to the ground, and the frame definitely didn't have a lot of give, but the cushions were beyond puffy. Which meant it was harder to heft my bulk out, but easier to get to my feet.

I waddled over to the couch, slightly proud and slightly alarmed that I was out of breath and coated with a fine misting of sweat from a 10 foot walk, if that. I mean, it was hot, but it also kinda sucked- I didn't want to think about what would happen when I couldn't get my own food by my own hand- with how much I ate, I'd need to hire at least two helpers. Still, the idea wasn't without merit...

I threw open the fridge and scowled. Granted, I wasn't the one who went grocery shopping (hardy har har har, I wouldn't make it... Well, ten feet) but we were still running low. Lately, I had been giving Rhonda a list that was two pages long and around a hundred bucks, and then working through the bounty by the end of the week. But, um... It was Wednesday. And the only thing in the fridge was a bowl of chicken noodle soup and a gallon of juice. "Shit!" I yelled in frustration as I grabbed the juice. I staggered back to the couch and popped off the lid, swigging down a solid third of the bottle while I pondered my options.

Pizza was fine, but repetitive. I had it yesterday, twice- one frozen, one fresh. A sandwich or three would be nice, but the nearest place, Tito's would probably take at least 45 minutes, and I needed that shit A.S.A.P..

I flipped through the nearby places on an app on my phone, when suddenly, the incoming call icon came on.

Incoming call from: Mother


Oh, shit. I felt myself tense up unwillingly at the sight of that name. Why was she calling? Honestly, I hadn't talked to her in... A long ass time. My dad had shot me a few emails, mainly asking how I was, and I had answered honestly and briefly- things were fine, I was fine, I had a job, blah blah blah.

I briefly thought about ignoring it, but realized that would probably make things worse. With a slightly shaking hand, I thumbed over the "Accept" button and raised the phone to my ear.

"H- hello?" I asked, timidly.

The voice was immediate and the same I remembered it sounding- judging and belittling and frustrating and a million other negative emotions... But there was almost something more to it, I thought. Or was I just imagining things?

"Hello, Melanie." And then silence. I began to panic- was Alice okay? Did they get a divorce? Did the house burn down? Why was she calling?!

I stared at the phone for a second, and then tried to play it cool. "Um, what's u-" I caught myself. Mother hated the term "What's up".

"How are thing's going at home?" I managed to blurt out, hopefully sounding calm.

There was a sigh on the other end. I waited it out- I vaguely recalled hearing or reading somewhere that speaking first in a period of importance was often a sign of weakness- and if there was ever a "period of importance", it was pretty much... Well, every time I talked to my mother.

1431132311123212132212211212221321232211.content:
“I just wanted to call you and… to talk to you.” There was a slight pause, “I… I miss you, Melanie.”

So I had all these really great lines saved up, right? I’d been living with my Aunt Rhonda for more than a year now; I’d been devoting time strictly to coming up with awesome one-liners and fat-positive taunts that would stuff a potato in Mom’s tailpipe. Mom finally calls me after not even speaking to me for more than three hundred and sixty five days, not even sending me a damn Christmas present, and she had to go and say that. Just…

Damn, y’know? It really took the wind out of my sails to hear her finally admit that she missed my adorable ass.

“I…uh...” I was in uncharted territory here; Moth—er, Mom and I had never exactly been the closest of Carlyles, “I miss you too?”

Ever since I had been a little girl, my MotherMom and I had been at each other’s throats. Not always because of my weight either (that didn’t start until I started to pork up at Buttercombe!), but for really stupid shit. What clothes I was going to wear, who I was or wasn’t going to hang out with, and even what I wanted for dinner eventually evolved into what clothes I should have been able to fit into but couldn’t, why I spent all my time eating instead of having a bustling social life, and what I wouldn’t be having for dinner as my weight got more and more “out of hand” (pff, whatever that meant). Even now that I was nineteen going on twenty, hearing my Mom actually admit to missing me was… weird.

“So… your Aunt Rhonda tells me that you two got a new couch.” My mother said flatly

I cringed in anticipation of a high-volume tirade, but no such rant came. She was actually going to dialogue with me.

“Uh… yeah.” I stammered, “S’a… It’s really comfy.”

I slumped further down into said couch. It really was comfortable, not that Mom cared. It didn’t creak or groan underneath all my big blubbery self, so it had to have been specially reinforced—a smart move on Aunt Rhonda’s part. I awkwardly drummed my belly with my plump fingers, sending ripples across its surface as I watched, mesmerized by the motions. I had never so badly wanted to eat comfort food in my entire life.

“Do you mind if I ask what happened to the old one?” there was a small release of air on the other end of the line that I, at first, mistook for a sigh. But then I heard the distinct movement of her vocal chords behind it; a very human sounding emotion.

Had she… had she just joked with me?

“I kind’ve… broke it.” I said sheepishly, “Well, me and my friend did. It’s a long story.”

“I’m sure.” My mother’s tone was surprisingly light, considering that I had just told her that me and my massiveness were at least in part for the decimation of my Aunt’s couch, “Well it’s not like you don’t have a history of destroying furniture.”

At that snide remark, my chest immediately puffed up. My indifferent expression immediately turned into a pudgy scowl as I frowned into the receiver, ready to unleash a year’s worth of pent-up aggression towards her for kicking me out. But she managed to cut me off. Bitch rage-blocked me.

“I-I’m sorry, I didn’t mean it like that…” she said in a sad(?) tone, sounding oddly human for the first time in ever, “I… I was just teasing.”

“Yeah.” I snarled, “Look Mom, thanks for calling, but I’ve really—“

“R-Rhonda says you have a job now!” she blurted out, making me halt my abrupt hanging up, “A-And that you… you’re doing a really good job at it.”

“Yeah.” I said a little more softly, putting my ear back to the reciever, “What of it?”

“W-Well it’s just… you know…” I didn’t, and I made sure to emphasize that with a pause, “I’m proud of you is all.”

Okay, that one took me by surprise. The last time I’d heard that sentence from her was at Patrick’s the day before she kicked me out, telling me how “proud” she was of her pig of a daughter for finishing off three chili cheese burgers, two corndogs, an order of onion rings, and a side of macaroni and cheese. In fact, I don’t think I’d ever heard that come out of her mouth without sarcasm…

“Th… Thank you!” I said a little too eagerly, “I, uh… I learned all my work ethic from Dad.”

There was another laugh on the other end of the line (seriously, who was this woman?!) at that. It sounded… sadder, somehow. Then there was a sniffle, something that I really hadn’t expected coming from an emotionless robot like my Mom.

“Mel, I just wanted to let you know that I’m not mad at you anymore.” I could hear her voice cracking on the other end of the line, “A-And that… I’m sorry I kicked you out.”

“And made me feel bad about my weight?” I fished before I even realized I had baited the hook, making me widen my eyes in shock. I didn’t want to sound like an ungrateful bitch, after all. This was the first sincere… anything from my mother I’d gotten in ever! I really didn’t want to screw it up…

“Of course I am. I love you!” she was definitely tearing up by now—I could hear it in her voice—“You’re my daughter, and I love you. I shouldn’t have kicked you out; i-it’s just… you make me so frustrated sometimes, a-and—!”

“Hey, it’s okay.” I said with a smile, starting to get a little choked up myself, “I can be a little hard to live with. Especially when I’m breaking couches.”

“No no, I’m at fault here, not you.” My mother sniffled, “I realize that now. Melanie, I called you because...

So, this was... Weird. I felt weird. If this wasn't all a ploy to somehow make me feel bad (and this new mom thing was about 20 hours old, so I wasn't putting it past her) then this would be the first time I saw my over-bearing, conniving, cruel, rude, bitc-... Okay, woah, woah. Hold your ground, Carlyle. Let's ease off the throttle just a little.

I mean, look. I moved out because of my mother- all those years of snide remarks that evolved into cruel comments that evolved into knock-down, drag-out shouting matches? Literally all my mom's fault. Hell, some psychologist would probably say my unending quest to become a blob was pretty much entirely because of my mom's attitude towards me growing up (and outwards). Still, I needed to calm down, find my Chi (thanks, Ms. Calliope, all those essays on Chinese culture... Sheesh), whatever. Even though our phone call went well, and ended well, I still found myself so stressed last night that I had devoured, well... let's say one doesn't go through an entire bottle of ranch without a LOT of chicken wings.

And then, this morning, I had been so worked up about meeting with my mother at the local mall, that I had to calm my nerves with two boxes of chocolate chip waffles, a box of chocolate chip frosted pastries, and... Chocolate chip ice cream. With chocolate on it. And then, the bus ride had just, like, SUCKED, so naturally I had gotten a malt two malts. In fact, I was just finishing the final bit of the banana-peanut butter one when I heard her voice.

I immediately whipped around and saw- well, my mom. Same as always. In fact, if I didn't get my facts mixed up, she was wearing the same dress she wore when... Well, when it happened. The final full day of my living at home...

"You shut your mouth, young lady, or I'll-"

"You'll fuckin' WHAT, mom? What will you do? I know you've never had a good day in your Goddamn LIFE but I am so sick of you trying to make me exactly like you! Guess what? I'LL NEVER BE LIKE YOU!"

"This has nothing to do about being like me, this has to do with being a healthy, productive, member of-"

"Oh, here we fuckin' go AGAIN. I literally JUST got home, MOM, and I don't need to hear this shit!"

I shook my head and cleared it. Let's see how things go here, first. No need to drudge up bad emotions until I knew they needed drudging. Or whatever.

"Hi, mom." I said flatly, still unsure what was going to happen- but what did happen, is she wrapped her arms around me- well, as best she could. As far as I could figure, the tips of her fingers barely angled around my back, and her bony arms sunk into my sides like mushing into a gigantic marshmallow.

I awkwardly hugged her back, taking care not to smother her with my hefty arms, which probably would force her so far in between my boobs that we'd need help getting her out, and that would probably dampen the mood a bit. Finally, we released, and as she pulled back, I saw that her eyes were shimmering ever so slightly with tears. "I, uh, missed you." I said awkwardly- but I could tell I was on the cusp of tearing up as well.

My mother, ever the stoic one, turned around and did one of those subtle wipes at her eyes, the kind people do when they're trying to be sneaky about wiping away tears. "I missed you as well, Melanie. I'm sure you're hungry- where would you like to go for lunch?" I balked- I was being offered food? What exactly happened between my mom and Rhonda?

"Oh, um, there's a pretty good mexican place-" But she was already walking towards it- an easy enough site seeing as it was about 8 feet away from us.

"Wonderful, let's get a table!" Well, so far so good. Although I was curious how this was going to play out...

1431132311123212132212211212221321232211.content:
I’ll admit that I was more than a little shocked when my mother—bane of my enormous existence—offered to buy me lunch.

I was even more shocked when she did so without so much as raising an eyebrow at the sheer size of my order. I mean, the cost alone of feeding me when I wasn’t upset wasn’t exactly cheap. But I had about a year’s worth of catching up to do with Mother Dearest, and that was going to make for one emotional fat girl. I planned ahead and ordered extra, just in case I felt the need to stuff my face a little extra to hold back tears (or maybe even get under my Mom’s skin a little—I wasn’t too sure how this was going to go down yet!) And she just… paid for it! Whipped out her debit card, handed it to the pimply teen behind the register, even got me a super-sized soda to wash it all down with! When she saw me huffing and puffing as I struggled to stand, instead of rolling her eyes and body-shaming me under her breath, she just told me to go sit down and that she would bring it all to me!

Weird right? I mean, I’ve said a lot about my mother. Caring and nurturing, even motherly isn’t a word that I would use to describe her usual treatment of me. But the Jan Carlyle that I saw that day was a noteworthy exception to the yelling, screaming, obeseophobic bitch that had been picking fights with me since I was old enough to talk. And when she came back to the table, armed with my smorgasbord? She just put it all down, smiling that same weird “I missed you” and divvied it up accordingly.

“So how’s my sister?” my Mother asked with a hopeful smile, sliding a foil-wrapped burrito across the table to me, “I haven’t seen her since I came to town.”

“She’s…” I mentally compared the Aunt Rhonda that I had known before my arrival and the bootilicious lady lawyer that waddled around the apartment currently, and decided that her weight was going to have to be a topic for another day. “Good. Rhonda’s doing good. How’s mine?”

I saw a similar expression flash across my Mother’s face as her practiced poise faltered, skipping a beat as she took her own meager portion of the meal for herself and freezing where she stood.

“She’s...certainly healthy.” My Mother said after her pause, “Just came back from her first year at Buttercombe—following, uh… in your footsteps, I suppose…”

I did my best not to smirk. Going by what I knew about Mom and what I knew about Buttercombe Academy, no doubt that was code for “Alice came home about fifty pounds heavier than when she left—and I don’t have anyone to blame it on since you’re gone.” But I kept that thought deep down inside; no use in poking the bear when she was obviously making a big effort not to chase me off. I decided to just eat my burritos and let it slide.

And so we just sort’ve… talked for a while. I mean, actually talking. Like, my food wasn’t getting cold or anything, but I had a lot to tell her. About Lily, about Marie, about Aunt Rhonda (besides her substantial weight gain, of course…) and about my new job. I was wise enough to omit the part about the whole “took me almost a year to get a job” thing, but other than that I was mostly straight up with my Mom for the first time in years. And surprisingly, she was pretty cool with almost everything I told her. I even made the casual mention that I was up more than a hundred pounds than I was when I left, and she just let it pass by coolly, not even one of those psychotic little twitches in her eye to be seen!

“Oof! M’stuffed!” I lied, patting my still pretty swollen stomach with one hand proudly, “Thanks a lot for lunch Mom.”

“It was nice, wasn’t it?” she said with a soft smile, “A-And you’re sure you got your fill, Melanie? If you’re hungry, I don’t—“

“Mom, stop.” I cut her off, “You don’t have to try and bribe me with food.”

“I’m not bribing you with food, Melanie.” My mom said a little crossly, making my colossal ass cheeks clench slightly, before she softened “I’m just… I want to make sure you’re okay. All this time away from you, not seeing you, not hearing from you because we—I’m so stubborn, it… I worry about you.”

Weird right? I had spent so long away from my Mom that I guess I sort’ve built her up in my head as this evil dietary overlord. The only times I really got to see her during my high school years were on Winter and Summer breaks, and we were always fighting… I never really got to see this side of my Mom. Like, at all!

Had she… had she always worried this much about me?

“Weeeelll… when you put it that way…” I smiled, rubbing my belly, “I guess I could go for a cookie or two.”

“Peanut butter?” my Mom asked with a knowing smile, “Two cookies, coming up.”

“Woah, hey, I’ll… I’ve got it Mom.” I said, scooching backwards in my seats and scraping the legs against the linoleum floor loudly, “You want one? I don’t mind.”

“Oh Melanie, no.” my Mother cooed (?!), “I couldn’t ask you to spend—“

“Hey, it’s my treat Mom.” I said, holding out my hands so she could come help me up, “Consider it my way of saying… y’know… thanks for lunch.”

1431132311123212132212211212221321232211.content:
So, I dished out like 2 bucks for our cookies. Pretty good way to end the day, right?

Wrong. My Mother continued deeper into the mall, and I followed along diligently, half of me not believing that this was real, thinking that this was some sort of fever dream brought on by some sudden psychotic break- and the other half of me thinking, "Hey, if my Mom is seriously talking to me like a living human being for the first time in years, I can't just ignore it".

So, despite my aching legs, carrying hundreds of pounds of wobbly, heavy fat, shouting mental warnings of "Yo, lard-ass, we shouldn't be up and moving like this", I carried on, quiet and collected.

It sounded like Alice was on the "gain-train", as it were. It also sounded like, at some point, Rhonda had essentially told her sister to chill out. So I was actually experiencing what I assumed most girls got to, well, actually enjoy- being at the mall with my Mom. So we walked.

And while I was initially bracing for the inevitable "Oh, Mel, you seem so... Tired..." Since I was sweating like I had just run a 25K sprint, it didn't happen.

And while I waited for the off-hand comment of "Oh, Mel, this is a cute dress... Not that it would, ahem, fit you..." It didn't happen- in fact, almost psychically, my mother asked if I'd like a triple-mocha frappe from the weird coffee chain when we passed by it- and of course, I said yes, and with a speed I didn't think was possible past the age of 20, my Mother Mom was in the line, ordering it for me, and paying.

But, there was something that could have broken anyone out of any trance- Hell, a man dying of thirst would've ignored a bottle of water for what both me and my mother Mom saw when I heard my name called out.

"Mel!" Went the voice- and there was a split-second, while I sipped on my "Frappe", and my head/neck lead my gut by a solid 3 seconds- where I thought some random stranger was calling out. I surely didn't recognize the voice. But when my eyes locked with theirs, I knew who it was immediately. And part of me panicked.

It was Lily- guess she had taken one of her rare excursions out of her apartment, her den of laziness, as it were, to go to the mall.

Thing is, she was crammed into something that wouldn't have worked for her rapidly fattening body back when I visited- and that was weeks ago! Now... Well...

Her gut hung out of a hoodie that- if my calculations were correct, based off how under-sized hoodies had worked for me in the past- should've been trashed 25 pounds ago, and that was if you were feeling generous. As for her shape, now? Well... Let's say there was more out in the air than there was covered.

Her tits had swelled, that was for sure- even with the small V-line of the hoodie zipped up (or what could be zipped, anyways) there was still a canyon of flesh oozing out that even made my massive mammaries look slightly smaller than what she was rocking. In fact, if some "regular" guy (or girl, I guess) was looking at her from the chest up, they may be too hypnotized to even notice the egregious amount of fat that existed below them.

But I didn't miss it. Her hips had swelled out in a way that necessitated stretch pants that couldn't be bought in any sort of store- which meant they smacked against passerby who thought maybe, just maybe, they could slip past the blob that was my best friend without slamming into her. But they were still brushed against.

"Uh, hey!" I yelled somewhat awkwardly. My Mom turned around as well, and I braced myself. At least I had made a decent attempt to not look like a slob. Lily looked like she had woken up 100 pounds fatter, and hadn't noticed yet. This was gonna be rough. Lily tottered up to me in a way that made her look like she had just learned to walk, but in truth probably just displayed how little she had walked since she had delved deeply into the gaining lifestyle.

She huffed and puffed with exhaustion as she arrived before me and my bewildered mother. "Do you... Mind helping... Me?" She asked, and I felt myself tense up.

"Um, Lil, now isn't the best time, I mean, I..."

She cut me off immediately, using her brief rest from physical movement as an opportunity to dive head-first into her request.

"No, I just need some help... With..."
1431132311123212132212211212221321232211.title: Mother, Meet My Massive Friend...

1431132311123212132212211212221321232211.content:
"I just need some..." Lily puffed, "Just bring me... food!"

Ugh, talk about lazy. Here I was worried that something might have been actually wrong—or at least that she actually needed my help with something—and all Lily wanted was someone to give her food. I mean she had actually walked up to me, so I guess that was a start. But I was with my up-til-then incredibly judge-y mother, so it wasn't exactly the best time for her to waddle up to me like she was ready to pop out of her clothes.

"Mel, who's this?" my mother asked from behind me, "And, um... is she... gonna be okay?"

"O-Oh!" I cringed, turning to face my mother as she looked the redheaded butterball up and down, "Th-This is, uh... this is Lily! Lily, this is... my mother! You know, the mother that I say that I have, sometimes?"

I was really, really hoping that I could escape my mother's meeting with Lily without blows coming to pass. Past experience told me that my mother was either going to say something snide about Lily's weight—be it anywhere from "oh, what ...good... company you keep these days, Mel!" to "don't tell me you've managed to turn this one into a fatass too, Mel?"—or that Lily was going to try and buck up to my Mom on account of all the shit that I'd told her over the past year or so.

"Hey." Lily said simply, giving me an accurate estimation as to how much my little ginger friend actually listened to me, "I'm Lily. It's nice to meet you, Mel's mom."

"Jan." my mother said with a tone I couldn't quite place, "I, um... I wish that I could say that Mel's told me a lot about you, buuuut..."

"Yeah, sorry about that." I said sheepishly, "Y'see, Lily's kinda my best friend here." I said that hoping that she wouldn't do anything gross (read: anything that I would totally have done if we weren't in front of my Mom) like burp or feel herself up, and she didn't disappoint, so I continued, "She goes to college in the area and—"

"Yeah yeah, whatever." Lily puffed, "Mel, are you and you Mom gonna eat any time soon? I'm starving. I came to see if they had any stretchpants that would fit me but all this food around me it's just... mmm!"

I watched as Lily started to rub her belly, squishing her doughy hands into the oozing freckled flab that hung out of her hoodie with an abject horror. Not at the sight, of course, but at my mother's percieved response to such flagrant lack of shame about her weight. That being said, even I usually waited until at least after I'd seriously met someone to give them the impression that I was more in love with my body than what they thought of me. And while I was hungry, I didn't really want to risk chasing off my Mom. Or adding more fuel to the fire—I still didn't know whether or not the new leaf my Mom had turned would hold up to one of my regular binges. While I certainly wasn't starving anymore, I wasn't... not hungry.

"Actually..." my mother answered for me, before I could so much as even think of a suitable lie...

1431132311123212132212211212221321232211.content:
I almost fainted.

We had just eaten. Literally just eaten, like, 10 minutes ago. I turned to my Mom inquisitively, but she was already talking to Lily. "Lily, is it? What are you hungry for?" Um, that seemed to be a silly question, I'm sure the real one would be what WASN'T she hungry for. But it seemed Lily already had the events planned out.

"I would absolutely love some chicken right now. Y'know, fried variant? Probably with potatoes, and rolls, and some mac and cheese, and-" I shot her a look so glaring harsh that I was almost positive her hair rippled. "I mean, Chicken Hut would be fine, if you don't mind joining me." Good to know Lily still knew how to talk like a damn human being, despite her earlier public display of self-love, as it were.

"Please, Lily, lead the way!" My Mom said cheerily. I balked, and she obviously caught my face, because she added- "I'd love to get to know my daughter's apparent best friend..." I decided to roll with it.

"Sure, yeah, let's go, Jan- I could eat, I suppose." I saw Lily open her mouth to shoot off some smarmy comment, but I cut her off with another stern gaze. She began to do her awkward waddle shuffle towards the Chicken Hut, which was only a few stores down, giving me and my mother a view of her ass. Again, I cannot reiterate this enough- those stretch pants couldn't even begin to stretch enough to accommodate her shimmying shelf of an ass. Each cheek rose, well, cheekily (no pun intended, probably) above the top of the pants by about an inch- something that probably would've been sexy to most folks if Lily was about 100 pounds lighter.

My Mom shot me a smile as we walked. "I was being honest, you know. I'd love to know more about your friend, here." I couldn't help but give her a small smile back.

"Well, Lily's been kinda absent lately, y'know, with college and all- it's the busy season and all..." I watched as Lily made a hard right turn into the highly anticipated Chicken Hut. She made a beeline for a booth and was squeezed inside it before we even rounded the corner. She waved a hand at us eagerly as we walked in- or so I thought, until I realized she was eagerly waving down a waiter.

"A coke and a chocolate malt please, and a basket of rolls for now- Hey, what do you guys want?" She asked quickly as we approached the booth.

"Water is fine, please." Jan Mom ordered.

"Um, just a coke, please." I said timidly. I was still unsure what exactly was happening here. Lily was staring at the menu, but it was pretty obvious she already knew what she wanted- it was just for show. I knew for a fact that the Chicken Hut near her apartment delivered, and I couldn't imagine she hadn't ordered from there before- I would assume she hit up everyplace that was within her delivery radius at least once a week... Hell, that's what I would do, anyways.

"So, Lily, tell me about yourself. What are you studying?" My Mom asked kindly- she, too, wasn't looking at the menu, but I assumed she probably wasn't going to be eating anything, since, again, we had just eaten.

"Well..." Lily began, and I felt myself get a little nervous... It occurred to me that it was very possible that she had gone even further down her path of laziness and had dropped out altogether. "I'm sort of in between majors at the moment." I waited for a comment from my Mom, but Lily knew what she was doing. "If you didn't know, in the first two years of college, over 80% of students change their major at least once. So-" She paused when our drinks came, to chug down half her coke in one go. "-I decided to just crank out my required courses right now- I'll declare a major after the semester when I have a better feel for what I want to do."

I had to admit- either Lily was a really good bullshitter, or she was being sincere. Our server had run off to drop off drinks to another table, but she was back in no time for the order...

Well, let's just say it wasn't pretty.

1431132311123212132212211212221321232211.content:
Okay, so, weird thing—my Mother was pigging out.

Like, seriously, my mother was pigging out.

Of all people, right?! You’d think that with her repertoire of being a fat-shaming, diet-pushing, “maybe you shouldn’t eat a whole batch of cookies in one sitting” bitchery, she would be the last person to try and keep up with us in a meal.

I say try because, for all her hard work, my mom was still a pretty scrawny woman. Not that I wasn’t impressed or surprised by her effort, but… it was really more of a snack as far as I was concerned. I didn’t really even notice that my mom had hit the “woah” mark until I stopped and watched just how much of the delivered food was going to her side of the table.

The pudgy waitress sat a bucket of fried chicken in front of my mom, which was in and of itself a sight to behold. But no, there was more. Apparently she had ordered the combo—that meant that a box of biscuits, a sizeable styrofoam container of mashed potatoes with gravy, and a large drink (Sprite?) were sat down to my awaiting mother. Said mother smiled eagerly and tipped the waitress (were you supposed to do that at the mall? I hadn’t been doing that…) as the rest of our food was doled out between us. My own meal took a whole other trip for the poor pudgy latina, but that didn’t stop Lily from digging in while they both waited.

My own meal had been relatively small, considering that I had just eaten with my Mom not even a few hours ago. I wanted to retain at least some semblance of normalcy, right? Prove to my mom that I wasn’t some hopeless pig who was gonna eat herself helpless before she turned twenty? You know, normal stuff that daughters proved to their mothers. I saw then that my modesty was misplaced, but by then I was too awestruck to really care.

“Mom, are you…?” my jaw hung slack, my neck roll bunching beneath it as I stared slack at the display before me, “That’s… a lot of food.”

“Oh p’shaww, what’s the harm?” my mother said as she held a big juicy thigh of greasy chicken above her breast, “How often is it that I eat dinner with my daughter and her friend? I think that a little celebration is in order…”

“Amen to that!” Lily cried out exuberantly with a burp, taking a punctuating slurp from her sweet tea, “Mel’s Mom, you’re the best!”

“Think nothing of it, Lily.” My mother said with a smile, “And please, call me Jan.”

Surprisingly, my mother punctuated her own sentence with a ravenous bite into her chicken. Seriously, she dove head-first into that thing. When she came up for air, red-orange sauce covered the corners of her mouth, completely challenging the image I had built up of my mother as this diet-crazy neatfreak. As she chewed, her cheeks bulging with chicken and sauce, I actually began to wonder if that was what I looked like—or rather, what I would have looked like in a few years if I dropped a few hundred pounds…

And as much as it surprised me, my mother only continued to keep up with us. She managed to take down most of her bucket, alternating her bites with globs of gooey mashed potatoes dripping with gravy and big heaping helpings of biscuit. She didn’t share, either! Lily and I were far too preoccupied with our own meals to notice her surprising affinity for overindulgence. She didn’t try to pawn off a piece, thigh wing or otherwise, even once. She was more than happy to rip into the sweet succulent meat all by herself, and reap the rewards of such indulgence…

By the time everything was said and done, I was sitting pretty full. Not only had I been binging all day in anticipation of my mother’s arrival, but I had managed to eat first supper and a second supper at the mall. New clothes be damned, I was pretty full. My mom had wound up treating me to pretty much all of the restaurants that the mall had to offer—and with me and Lily combined, the only one suffering more than my distended belly was her poor wallet.

“Oof.” My mom grunted as she leaned back in her chair, her stomach distended, “I think that’s enough for one day.”

Other than, of course, her poor stomach.

I had never seen my mother overeat before. Not even once. No holidays, no birthdays, not even on her birthday. I guess I more than made up for it with my indulgent eating habits, but I had just sort’ve figured that my mother was incapable of such a thing. But lo and behold, across the table was my Mommy Dearest, cradelling a tummy fully of chicken and Mexican food like it was nobody’s business. Beneath her floral top, a distinct bulge of belly pushed forward—not enough to be more pronounced than a bump, but certainly enough for me to take notice.

“Maybe for now.” Lily smacked her lips greedily, literally sucking the sauce off of her chubby fingertips, “You sure you don’t want dessert?”

“Oh..." my mom said politely, "I don't know..."

“Hey Mel, you up for some dessert?” Lily ignored my mother’s answer in favor of mine, one more surely in line with her level of comfort in obesity and overindulgence

“I, uh…” I listened to my gut gurgle, drumming the taut skin of my stomach from beneath my sweater, “I could eat a little more, if you’re up for it…”

I looked at my mom, hoping to test the new waters that we found ourselves in.

“Mom?” I asked, “You want some dessert?”

1431132311123212132212211212221321232211.content:
So... That was weird. Like, really weird. Sure, seeing my mom be... Nice, was a definite departure from the usual status-quo, but for her to pig out like that? Well, it was beyond the pale. So I wasn't going to say no, of course, but I wasn't entirely shocked when the offer of dessert was scoffed upon. "I... I really couldn't, Lily- in fact, I'm starting to..." She turned a little pale for a moment, and I waited for her to barf- thankfully, she didn't, just barely suppressed a hiccup. "Starting to feel a bit ill, perhaps my daughter could take me back to my sisters?"

I wasn't going to object. "No, Mom, that totally sounds great- like, really great. Why don't we get going?" I asked timidly- truth be told, I was pretty sure I couldn't handle a round of dessert- well, maybe a dessert fitting someone the size of... Er, my Mom, I guess- but certainly not the kind of dessert I was used to, at any rate. So it's best we moved on, rather than one of us explode. And judging by how pale my mother dearest currently was, I had a feeling that exploding sounded pretty alright to her at the moment.

Lily couldn't help but air her grievances. "Yeah, well... Guess I'll get some ice cream alone..." I shot her a look while my mom fished out her credit card. "I mean, not that there's, uh, anything wrong with that." She awkwardly shifted her bulk out of her booth, and I mouthed the words 'text me' at her as she slowly scooted out. She nodded- I figured there was a fifty-fifty chance of her remembering.

"Let's... Get this paid for... I need to lay down."

Several awkward moments later- and I mean awkward, because my mom couldn't stop panting loudly as we were rung out. I knew how she felt... Back when I started blimping up and secretly eating, I had overdone it several times... Well, more like a dozen... Well, more like six or seven times a week towards the end of my skinny phase and into my obese phase. Point being, I knew how she felt. When you're skinny and used to eating, oh, I dunno, like 300 calories a meal instead of 1500, it can really feel like dying when you overdo it. So when we waddled out of the restaurant and my mom handed me her keys to her SUV, I didn't even question it.

I could still drive... Right?

The seat was about 30 inches closer to the steering wheel than I would've liked, and even with it all the way back (which took several agonizing seconds of very slow motorized gears grinding while I stood there awkwardly, the upper half of my asscrack hanging out while I bent over to adjust it) my mom just reclined the passenger seat and groaned. I mean, she dressed conservatively and was practically a beanpole beforehand so it's not like her gut was jutting into the air like she was several months pregnant- if there was an impression on her outfit I couldn't see it. But as I revved up the engine and awkwardly backed out, I couldn't help but open my mouth.

"So... What brought that on?" I asked as bluntly as possible. Oops.

My mom grimaced. "Mel... I'm sure you remember when you first started... Getting larger." I winced.

Did I ever.

"I was... I was very rude about it. That's because... My Mother was not nice about my body. Or my sister's. She was... Very old-fashioned. I... When we had you girls, I was so happy, but as time went on, some things that... That your grandmother taught me, came back, I suppose." I tried to remember my Grandma- the one on my mom's side- and struggled. I wasn't sure if I had even met her. But since we were in psychotherapy 101, I supposed I had no choice but to listen.

"Anyways, I took that out on you, and to a lesser extent, Alice. But after Alice came home... Erm... Larger... I realized that, maybe I had been... Wrong about a few things. And while I will admit that the food we ate today was tasty..." I heard her suppress another hiccup, or maybe a burp- I wasn't sure. "I don't... I don't think I can eat quite like you do. But I wanted... I wanted you to know that I will always love you, and I will understand if you want to, well, eat like your friend Lily does."

I could almost feel myself tear up. "Mom... I... I'm not sure what..." I began, but she was already waving her hand in the air dismissively.

"Just get us to my sister's. I need to lay on a couch or something, before I drive home... Talk to Rhonda..." And then her head lolled to the side. She was in food coma territory- a situation I knew all too well. Hopefully she took her sister's gain as well as me and my sister's...

1431132311123212132212211212221321232211.content:
So I got Mom back to my Aunt Rhonda’s place alright.

I mean, as alright as I could have possibly gotten her there. My mother may have turned over a new leaf as far as her attitude towards my weight went, but her car surely hadn’t. I had scooted that thing as far back as it could go, and I still wasn’t exactly driving safely. I had to suck it in as much as I could just to keep my belly from bunching up against the steering wheel constantly. But I digress.

I woke my mom up once we made it to the parking lot, and we slowly made our way out of the vehicle and onto to asphalt. I poured myself onto the ground, my feet aching after the minimal amount of effort I had put into walking all day. Not to mention the fact that I was particularly full—not stuffed mind you (I had come home far fuller in the past!) but enough to at least feel some mild discomfort—and had spent far too much energy emotionally reconciling with my mother.

Who, might I say, wasn’t exactly up for the long walk up to the main building either. Her own surprise binge had left her rather ill-suited towards much movement. She trudged, dragging her feet along the dirty pavement and scuffing up her Toms. Who knew I got my “I don’t wanna walk” look from my mother of all people?

Anyway, so we made it to the main building and waited for the elevator. I knew not only by the events of the day, but by the bulging of both our bellies, that my mother would not chastise me for doing so for probably the first time in years. We piled in, slumped against the wall, and waited patiently for the third floor to arrive as we clutched our respective tummies.

We made it up alright, waddled down the hall, and I shoved my key in the door before busting in belly-first, my mother not far behind me…

“Thank gawd you’re home.” I heard my aunt call out from what sounded like the living room, “Do we have any more of that cookie dough ice cream?”

We waddled in to the sight of my Aunt Rhonda, beached on the couch. She had one thick leg kicked over the back, bent at the knee and bobbing lightly, as her tummy splayed free from the confines of her Apple Dumplin’s t-shirt; lightly bronzed skin swelling out and pooling on the couch beside her. Her cute black bob was a mess, and her front showed the tell-tale signs of having missed a scoop or two of what looked like some kind of marinara sauce. She turned to look at me, and as soon as she saw my mom walk in behind me, her eyes nearly shot right out of her head.

“Oh my God!” my aunt moved faster in that second than I had seen her move in months, rolling her bottom-heavy body off the couch and jiggling quickly into her bedroom, “Mel, why didn’t you tell me my sister would be here?!”

“I told you I was meeting her.” I snarked, stifling a belly laugh as my mother chucked amusedly behind her hand, “You thought you’d get off that easy? No way, if I’ve gotta see her, so do you!”

There was much fun to be had at Rhonda’s expense as she quickly changed into something more presentable—an outfit that was comfortable, but not “thunder-thighs on the loose, belly rolling out like a storm front” comfortable. My mother and I, from the living room, threw a couple of catty remarks about her state of undress at her through the door, something I never thought we’d ever do. At least not together. Before too long, my aunt reemerged, squeezed into a pair of sweatpants and another shirt that hugged her hippy hugeness.

“Rhonda.” My mother said warmly, wrapping her sister in a hug, “It’s so good to see you.”

“You too, Jan.” my Aunt said, still flustered, before giving me the evil eye over my mom’s shoulder, “Your daughter is dead.”

“I would expect nothing less.” My mother chuckled, “Now come on, I need to… sit. Please.”

***


And so, we sat.

We sat and we talked and we ate a little (that was really more me and my Aunt, less so my mother) and honestly it was literally the best time I had ever had with more than one member of my extended family.

I mean, oh my god, I had never heard these two women carry on like they did that night. I guess it sort’ve came with the territory of being shipped off to Buttercombe Academy, and in no small part thanks to Aunt Rhonda living farther down the East Coast. But I really felt like an adult, sitting there and listening to my mom and my aunt trade stories and take digs at one another and all that stupid crap that sisters did. In fact, they sort’ve reminded me of me and Alice. Y’know, if Alice could take a joke.

“Yeah well I’ll have you know that your daughter made me fat.” My Aunt said with a semi-self-conscious pat to her bloated belly, though her laugh was genuine, “In fact, I think you just shipped her off to me because you were tired of being the ugly sister!”

“I don’t think my daughter has anything to do with those hips of yours, Rhonda.” My mother said with a laugh, “She inherited my chest. You just got stuck with Mom’s hips and you’re upset about it.”

My Mom and I shared a belly laugh (us! Laughing!) as Rhonda shrunk into her shoulders, taking a curmudgeonly bite out of the recovered cookie dough ice cream. The joke was well-placed and meant innocently, something that even Rhonda could see. It had clearly been some time since these two had sat down and gotten to talk like this. I’d like to think that Rhonda was just as shocked as I was that my mom had become so… tolerable lately.

In fact, the worst thing she did that evening was sneak a peek at her cell phone…

“Oh my, look at the time.” My mother yawned, “I’d better be getting to bed. Sleep off our little dinner.”

“Oh no, come on!” I plead, “Stay up—we still have some ice cream in the fridge, right?”

“No no, I’d better get to bed.” My mother said with a smile as she rocked her still swollen self up off of the couch, “I’ve got a long drive ahead of me.”

“Take my bed.” My aunt burped, “I’ll crash out on the couch tonight—‘sides, I’ve got a long night of Netflix to catch up on.”

For the first time in years, I got a good-night hug from my mom. And she didn’t even bitch when she couldn’t wrap her arms around me—it was so nice. So serene. I felt like a little kid again—which, I mean, I didn’t really get along with mom when I was little, but… y’know, making up for lost time, right? And she hugged my Aunt Rhonda, and it was nice, and then she just went down the hall, into my Aunt’s bedroom.

“Wow.” My aunt said with genuine astonishment, “What happened?”

“I know, right?” I answered her excitedly, “She’s so… different now.”

“Tell me about it.” My aunt whistled, “Your mom hasn’t been this cool in years—not since Mom died.”

“Really? What happened?” I asked, hoping to expand on that mental note I’d made about Grammy Burkhart near the end of our Mommy-Daughter binge, “Like… were she and my mom close or something?”

“Pssh! Hardly.” My aunt snorted, “Mother was a real—“

she stopped, visibly censored herself, and continued,

“—mean person.” She continued flatly, “She spent our entire lives making me and your mom feel like shit about our bodies. And I guess once she died, your mom just sort’ve… picked it up. I don’t know. I’m a lawyer, not a psychologist.”

“I can’t imagine anyone worse at fat-shaming than Mom is. Was. Whatever.” I said with a roll of my eyes, “Seriously, the woman’s a stick. Grandma would have had to have been, like, a super stick to make my Mom feel bad about herself.”

“Actually…” my aunt pursed her lips before continuing…

1431132311123212132212211212221321232211.content:
"Yeah, I mean, we weren't the skinniest kids... Or teens." I gawked at her. I tried to recall any pictures of my mom before the age of 28 (when she was first pregnant with me, shortly after her and dad got married) and I honestly couldn't. At all. "I mean, your mom was always heavier than me, of course..."

I cocked an eyebrow at her in disbelief.

"Well... Well, she was taller!" She said defensively. "And older... Look, that's not important!" I nodded in a way I hoped wasn't too condescending- I actually was pretty damn interested in this.

"No, please continue." I busied myself by digging a spoon into some cookie dough ice cream that I had pilfered from the freezer- I had miraculously made some room after my mom went to bed.

Aunt Rhonda blew some air from between her lips. "Anyways. Yeah, it started when we were kids. Your Grandpa- do you even remember him?" I shook my head- him and my Grandma had passed not shortly apart. "He- Well, he was a chef. I mean, he was the best chef. I think he didn't grow up in a very well-off family, and he learned to cook with what he had- and by the time him and Mom were able to, you know, actually afford food, he really took it up." I stared at her, entranced. I almost forgot about my ice cream. Almost.

"He was big on making meals- hearty meals. Our Mother- your Grandma- she usually ate about 3 bites and then got pissed off that we weren't, and I quote, 'rationing our food'. So he'd cook in secret. And when you're a kid, you don't understand..." She started to trail off.

"I think I get it, Aunt Rhon-" I started, but she waved a hand in the air.

"No, no, I mean, I don't think you do." She was frowning now, and I was starting to regret asking about this in the first place. "Your Grandpa was very kind to us- he'd sneak us snacks, baked pasteries he made from scratch, bacon when we were in our rooms- it's kind of surprising that we weren't, you know, bigger than we ended up. But when we were teens, going into high school, well, that's when Mom got really..."

She trailed off, but I already knew where she was going with her thought. "I think I get it."

She looked at me sadly. "Yeah. I'm sure you do. That's why... That's why it's weird, to see my sister act like this. What do you think happened?"

I paused for a second. "Well, if one daughter getting fat wasn't enough, I guess Alice got a little taste of Buttercombe, and it was a bit of an eye-opener for mom..."

Rhonda stared at me for a second before bursting out laughing. I let her get it out of her system. "You getting as big as you did didn't do it, but Alice puts on, what, twenty pounds and she breaks? I mean..." I stared at her for a bit, not quite getting why it was so funny. She finally recovered, as I took the last bite of my ice cream.

"I mean, Mel- it's just, she... She was the older sister, and she watched me get rounder than her, and she... Ha, oh, I mean, she just kinda- dropped the weight, while I just grew into it, if that makes sense... I just- Oh, you would've had to have been there, I guess. It's just ironic..." I was completely lost at this point.

"Look, she's being nice now- that's all that matters. We should probably get some bed- can I borrow a few blankets?" I nodded vigorously, my chins folding into themselves. As I pushed myself off the couch, grunting from the effort, my Aunt grabbed my thick wrist. "Mel, I'm serious- don't say anything to your mom about this, okay?"

1431132311123212132212211212221321232211.content:
Okay, so barring the fact that I couldn’t quite get the mental image of my mother as “chubby” (whatever the hell that meant anymore), I actually slept pretty well that night. Nothing that half a pack of those dollar lemon cookies and a glass of whole milk couldn’t fix. In fact, I slept like a baby—reconciling with my mother had put me in the best place that I had been in… since I could remember, actually!

So imagine my feelings when, just as we were starting to get along, my Mom had to head back home.

“Noooo, please?” I whined, “Can’t you at least stay for breakfast?”

“Mel, we already had breakfast.” My mother put her hands squarely on her hips, belly bulging

“Well yeah but… but I’m still hungry—that was only the first course!” I plead, turning to my Aunt Rhonda

“To be fair… I could go for some donuts.” My aunt said with a sleepy scratch of her doughy stomach, “We were kinda holding back for your sake.”

Despite my knee-jerk reaction of expecting condemnation for being so openly greedy and emotional, my mother simply gave a small sigh that tickled the corners of her mouth into a slight smile.

“I swear, you two are incorrigible—you deserve each other.” She said with a little laugh, “But I have to go. I could only get the one day off, and I’ve got a long drive ahead of me.”

With much struggling, my aunt, mother and I managed to get me to a standing position. I was on a semi-full stomach after all, and it wasn’t like either of them were working out. As soon as I was on my chubby feet, I wrapped my arms around my Mom for the first time in forever and gave her a big, squishy bear hug. She wrapped her own bony little arms around me as far as she could reach, her forearms sinking between two of my more prominent side-rolls.

“Be good, Mel.” She gasped, struggling under my weight, “Love you.”

“Love you too.” I squeezed even tighter, eliciting a familiar gasping noise from deep within my mother as I squeezed the life out of her, “Tell Daddy and the Squirt I said hi.”

“Oh, right…” my mother pushed away from me, and I released her. She looked like a tomato ready to pop—I guess I didn’t realize my own fat girl strength, “About Alice… she was wondering if she could come visit you? After the semester lets out, of course.”

“Really?!” I squealed, my chubby hands clapping together with such force that it sent my whole body shaking

“Well I told her what… happened a while back.” My mother paused as she knowingly glossed over the fact that she had kicked me out, “And she was so distraught over not getting to see you over the Summer, so I told her that I’d ask your Aunt Rhonda about it and… well…”

Two sets of eyes turned to face my Aunt Rhonda, currently half-way through a bear-claw that had managed to escape her binge last night. Her gaze shifted towards us, her cheeks bulging as she stood leaned against the counter, belly pouring onto its surface. She stared at us like a deer caught in headlights.

“Uh… sure?” my aunt looked around, as if shocked that we were actually asking her permission

That was all I needed to hear—I was so excited that I iterally started to jump up and down.. kinda. And then I calmed the fuck down once I realized just how exhausting and dangerous (for myself and the apartment, and the Fitzgerald family a floor below us) that shit was. But I was still fucking ecstatic. I loved my little sister to death, and I hadn’t seen her in forever! In fact, the last time I had seen her was literally the day before my mom kicked me out—I was honestly worried that I wouldn’t see her again, given that she was in Buttercombe and I was in a different state than where she left me.

“Yay!” I squealed, “This calls for a celebration—I’ll get the ice cream.”

“We ate the ice cream.” My aunt managed through her mouthful of bear claw, ”Like, six hours ago. Remember?”

“Then order more donuts! Apple Dumplin’s delivers, right?”

“Mel, I really shouldn’t—“

But I wasn’t having any of that. I was going to see my little sister for the first time in a year—the little squirt that I had literally tried to be the best big sister to in the history of ever. We had been so tight before I left, even though I spent most of my time at Buttercombe. We’d stay up late, watch movies, not tell Mom we did either of those things, eat some snacks while we swapped stories about our respective school lives, it had been so great. And now she was coming here! To me! Because she missed me!

If that didn’t call for emergency-delivery-donuts, I don’t know what did.

***


Anyway, so my Mom left after a couple donuts. Then me and my Aunt went out and got lunch, which eventually turned into lupper. I emailed Ms. Calliope before dinner and told her about what had happened the night before, and why I had suddenly gone dark, and she was pretty okay with it. Then I texted Lily and Marie, filled them in… it was all pretty exhausting, if you want the truth.

But I digress—my Aunt and I spent the next three months getting ready for Summer to start. We figured that since Al couldn’t drive, she’d be staying a bit longer than my Mom had; at least a few days. So we bought this cot bed that rolled underneath my own for her to sleep on (I couldn’t offer my sister my bed like my Aunt Rhonda had, I was way too fat to sleep on the couch!) and we made sure that the house was stocked with extra groceries so that there’d be enough food for the three of us (…for a while.)

In that time, all my ‘celebration-binging’ meant that I’d managed to gain another forty pounds; all of it seemingly going straight to my belly. That officially meant that I was too fat to drive. I had managed to drive my mom’s big-ass SUV, but that was only just barely. And since my Aunt Rhonda had to work, that meant that we couldn’t really drive up to Buttercombe and pick my sweet little sister up like I wanted to. So we sprung for a plane ticket—gotta love that sweet, sweet lawyer money!

I wasn’t quite sure what to expect, if you wanted the truth. My mom had made it a point to tell me that Al had gotten “bigger”, but she had carefully avoided telling me just how much bigger “bigger” was. It was probably something to do with her new sensitive attitude towards our weights, but it didn’t exactly give me a good idea of what exactly had happened to my sweet little sister. After all, Buttercombe Academy was the most posh, luxurious private school in America, and they pampered all of their students. I gained fifty pounds without even trying when I was Alice’s age; and that was before Christmas.

So anyway, my Aunt Rhonda was the one who had to go get Alice. Not only was I too big to fit in the driver’s seat, but even getting in and out of the back seats was becoming a hassle. I’d stayed home and made sure that everything was ready for Alice’s arrival—and of course, excitement-eating a sizeable portion of the snacks and groceries we’d bought for her arrival.

It was six ‘o’ clock on a Monday in late May when Alice finally arrived, and I saw the damage for myself...
1431132311123212132212211212221321232211.title: Awaiting Alice's Arrival

The next day, I decide to take Alice to meet Marie and Lily!
Before we go to bed, Alice tells me some juicy stories about the past year...
1431132311123212132212211212221321232211.content:
So, I was just finishing up my email to Ms. Calliope- she had sent me this incredibly over-the-top gift basket as a thank you for helping her absolutely crush it during finals week, so I sent her an overwhelmingly gushy and heartfelt thank you as I munched on the third KitKat from the damn thing. I told her to enjoy her month off before we started prepping for next semester (I knew I would- not that I didn't already have like, the lowest effort job ever, but it'd be nice to literally focus on nothing but my eating and my sister and on some nice evenings in with Marie and Lily- not that those two needed any help in the eating department...

Anyways, I was trying my hardest not to get little chocolately crumbs on everything when the buzzer for the door rang. I slammed my laptop shut and shuffled to my feet, my belly flopping loosely over the top of my yoga pants- but that was just how I had to wear pants now, with my gut aggressively (and gloriously) rolling over the top and down towards my thighs. I didn't even bother trying to pull my sweatshirt down, as I knew the most I'd do is cover a few inches for half a second until I jiggled it back up.

I eagerly pressed the door button for a solid 3 seconds and then glanced back at the coffee table, where the snacks were.

Well, most of the snacks. Okay, about half. Half sounded right. The ranch Doritos were gone, as was most of the queso-dip, but I had been good and left the ruffled potato chips and the sour cream dip alone, other than a few test bites. I had rearranged the cupcakes so it looked like there was only supposed to be six instead of twelve, and I had even disposed of the Apple Dumplin's box and arranged the assortment on a plate so it looked like they were all there- although I was hoping Aunt Rhonda wouldn't notice the missing chocolate eclair- oh who was I kidding, I knew she would...

And then the door was open and it was kind of a blur for a second and then I was hugging my little sister and trying not to tear up too much. Look, I may play it cool most of the time but I hadn't seen Alice in for-ever! It was a very touching scene, let me tell you.

"Mel I missed you so much-"

"Alice I can't believe you're here-"

"-So much to tell you about Buttercombe-"

"-Do they still have the build your own burger Fridays-"

"-And I even took a cooking class-"

Anyways, eventually we both calmed down a bit and sat down on the couch- well, both couches. At some point my ass had gotten to a point (don't ask me how) where, combined with my aunt's rather generous hips, we couldn't quite both fit on the couch. So now the living room was slightly rearranged, with two couches sort of crookedly facing the television, with a coffee table in-between. It was a nice, open set up. Alice was crammed on the couch next to me- which really put into perspective how big she had gotten.

Now, keep in mind, when I went to Buttercombe, part of me was on a mission. And it was to piss off my mom. So I ate and ate and ate- I ate myself sick on several occasions, but I just pushed myself, and watched while my roommate, classmates and friends all expanded- but I expanded twice as fast.

So while I was half-expecting my timid little sister to come back with a little paunch, or maybe a few extra pounds in the hip area, I wasn't suprised to see her come back- well, as heavy as she was. In my head, I figured she about kept pace with the girls I knew in Freshman year.

Still, it was super weird to see my formally twig-thin sister with an additional 30-40 pounds on her frame. Not that it didn't suit her just fine, in my eyes. She was a little shorter than me, and definitely took on more of an apple shape, just like her old sister- no one area gained significantly more, but a potbelly was definitely the first thing you'd notice on her. She was crammed into a sleek looking sweatshirt that probably fit well five pounds ago, but now emphasized her little tummy, and yoga pants- a growing girl's best friends. I was brought back to the conversation by a sharp prodding in my ribs- well, the fat surrounding my ribs, anyways.

"No way!" She was exclaiming, happily munching away at a bowl of potato chips and giggling, her eyes bright with laughter.

"Yeah, and get this- she thought I wouldn't notice!" My aunt was doubled over on her couch, her belly pushing up her own sweatshirt and causing a bit of belly to ooze out.

Oh, right. She was telling the couch story. Of course she was.

"I didn't think you wouldn't notice!" I said defensively, although I was laughing too. "I just thought maybe it wasn't so bad..." I guiltily bit into a glazed donut.

"Mel, the couch was practically at a 45 degree angle..." She said, before reaching for a cupcake off the coffee table.

I just sighed.

So we sat and talked and laughed- Alice told me all about Buttercombe, how much fun she was having- I talked about how much fun Rhonda and I were having out here, how fucking awesome my job and life was, we even talked about mom a bit.

"Yeah, she- she wasn't super happy when I came home, at first anyways..." Alice had gone a bit red- for most of the night, she was like a whole different girl, but this was the first sign of my quite, slightly awkward sister.

I sighed. I remembered how it all started back when I came home from Buttercombe.

"But! She quickly dropped the issue, which was nice. There were a few nights where she'd make this gross stuff for dinner, but I think Dad kind of got on her case about it- he was the one who encouraged her to call you..." She looked at me for a minute, smiling. "But I may have been the one to give him that idea." I grinned back.

"Well, your master plan that was about as blunt as a shovel worked, girl, because you're here!" Rhonda yawned from the couch. When I glanced at the clock, I realized it was almost 10:30!

"I gotta get up in the morning, girls- try and keep it down, okay? Alice, I'm really glad you're here!" She stood up and gave Alice a quick hug, and me one as well, awkwardly jamming my face into her chest from the couch.

"Yeah, goodnight, we will!"

"I'm glad I'm here too!" Alice said, beaming.

"So..." I said as Aunt Rhonda closed the door. "What are we gonna do before bed?"

Alice looked at the coffee table, which still had a fair amount of food on it. "Um... Finish off these snacks?"

I couldn't have been more proud.

1431132311123212132212211212221321232211.content:
So I figured late that night, what better way to show off my little sister than to parade her around to the two people that I actually knew? Ms. Calliope had given me the month off, and Aunt Rhonda was at work anyway. It wasn’t like we really had anything better to do; why not introduce her to Lily and Marie?

Around noonish (just coming off of brunch, just in time for lunch!) Alice and I took a bus to the mall. There were officially no taxis in South Carolina that could haul me around as effectively as public transportation, so I was beginning to make ready use of it. My ass was so wide that I took up three seats, meaning that I literally needed an entire row of seats to sit comfortably—because God knows I was not about to stand for that long.. Alice sat on the row beside me, next to a few gawkers who looked from her to me like “oh shit, you’re related?”. Not the best first bus experience for her, but the overall bumpiness of our ride meant lots of jiggling for me, and that meant that I garnered more than my fair share of attention.

As our valiant chariot came to a gasping stop, I needed Alice’s help along with a few less-judgmental fellow passengers, to get myself to a standing position. In less than a hundred pounds or so, I was probably going to have to stop these little outings altogether. I was getting too damn heavy for my own good, and while I knew that maybe I should slow down just a little I knew that it was an eventuality for me. The next step was recruiting the cast of Supernatural and/or Arrow to wait on me hand and foot, and my dreams would be fulfilled.

Anyway, back on track, Mall. Alice. Me.

Alice was pretty awestruck by just about everything we passed; I had to remember that before she left for Buttercombe, Alice had never been so much as out of our hometown. Coming to a different state where just about everything was the same as it was back home, just moved around a little (and maybe a bit more humid, with a southern drawl) was probably groundbreaking for her. Me? I was too busy heaving and sweating and sputtering like an old engine to really take in the novelty of my surroundings. Just the walk from the bus stop to the entrance of the mall had me ready to collapse. I did my best to play it cool, but damn it was hot! And I was not well-suited for high-temperature climates! I hadn’t exercised this much in months, and I was exhausted and starving!

So I waddled through the double doors belly first, Alice toddling behind me, when I saw Lily and Marie in my peripheral. The familiar scent of grease and salt kept my brain so addled that it took me a full minute to register that we weren’t here so I could stuff my fat face, we were here to introduce Alice to my blubbery besties.

“Hey Mel!” Lily called out, waving her doughy, wobbling arm, “Over here!”

I let out a puff of air—well, a more pronounced puff of air. One that hopefully showed that I would much rather have just started eating right off the bat—and steered my bulk towards the conglomeration that had been prepared for our inevitable feast.

“Sup fatties?” I huffed, plopping down into three seats comfortably, “Surprised you guys didn’t get started without me.”

“Trust me, Lily tried.” Marie stuck her tongue out at the increasingly overweight redhead, who shot her a dirty look, “But I knew that today was a special occasion.”

“Spe—oh, right.” Again, hungry. Don’t think so good when hungry. “Ladies, this is Alice—Alice, this is Lily and Marie.”

Alice took a shy step forward, her hands held behind her back as she shrunk into herself. She was still wearing her sweatshirt from yesterday, meaning that her cute little belly was outlined very plainly—no mystery who’s sister she was, after all—and her jeans were tight enough to give everyone a clear view of her muffin top bulging over them. Her chubby little cheeks burned bright red as she smiled awkwardly at my friends.

“Hi.” She squeaked, taking a seat next to me, “I’m Alice.”

Marie gave a little nod and a big smile to Alice, welcoming her into our little gaggle of fatties officially I guessed. Marie had only continued to put on weight in her continued exposure to me and Lily. The sweet, spoiled little rich girl who’d never had junk food had put on quite a bit of weight before the summer started. I could comfortably categorize her as “chubby” now, closing in on the “fat” title very quickly. It figured that all that time on her butt, scarfing down junk food with two fat pigs like me and Lily would make her ass more comfortable to sit on. She wasn’t quite as bootilicious as my Aunt Rhonda as far as proportions went, but my Catholic school snack attacker was a definite pear. Her tummy eeked out of her yoga pants (again, big girl’s best friend!) and onto her well-padded lap, eager to be filled with the day’s binge.

“Nice to finally meet you—Mel hasn’t shut up about you for weeks.” Marie said plainly as yet another laugh was shared at my expense, “But no, seriously, she’s sweet. You’ve got a good sister.”

A burp signaled Lily’s incoming input into the conversation. She definitely hadn’t given up her goal of outclassing me, or of becoming the biggest she could get. Her new battle plan of staying in her dorm all day, eating her weight in junk food while she coaxed through her easy-ass online curriculum had certainly been paying off. Lily was nearing the big three double zero after only a year’s worth of hanging out with me—in maybe another twenty or thirty pounds, she’d reach it. My little ginger binger had become unrecognizable from the skinny little thing she started as. Her belly was huge, lapping over every waistband she owned with pride and folding into two meaty rolls that jiggled with her every step. Her fat ass tested the limits of her single chair—I theorized that ‘300’ would come with the necessity with a chair under each cheek at her height and overall girth—just as much as her top was tested by her titanic tits. Seriously, she was exploding out of that thing. They were resting on the table and everything.

“Except when she keeps us waiting for an hour.” Lily said huskily, “M’starved. Can we eat yet?”

“Gawd yes.” I whined, “I’m exhausted.”

We waited for a sec, let me get my bearings, and then we all went off to order obscene amounts of food without caring about the consequences. Alice stuck mostly by my side while Lily and Marie stuck together, then we all came back with way too much food in tow, and started stuffing it in our faces.

Sounds fun, right?

Well everything was going great until…
1431132311123212132212211212221321232211.title: Acquainting Alice with my Fatass Friends

1431132311123212132212211212221321232211.content:
So things were pretty damn rad.

I loved being around Lily and Marie, because Marie was encouragement (in her own, possibly unintentional way) and Lily was competition (in her definitely intentional way- I wasn't too dumb to realize she constantly tried to out-eat me) so I usually put myself through the paces, as it were.

And it just so happened that, since I had burned about three times the amount of calories getting to this particular establishment than I usually did in an entire day, that I was pretty much "face down, ass up" into my food, as the kids say- which means I basically was in the zone while I munched down piles of fatty foods. In fact, I was only half-way through my second course, which was, of course, slightly larger than the first, before I realized that everyone wasn't entranced by their food- there was one person who was actually talking.

And it was Marie.

Lily was probably reaching a point where she'd consider her meal a snack, if her growth rate was any sort of indication.

Alice was- in all likelihood- used to Buttercombe portions, which meant that her current platter was a bit larger than usual (not a knock against Buttercombe, they just tended to prefer quarter pounders over half pounders, eight chicken tenders over twelve- you get it), but Marie?

Well, it was obvious she had gotten chubby by being around Lily, but that also meant that she was used to Lily's eating habits. Which meant she knew all sorts of tips and tricks that she had probably subconsciously learned from Lily.

"Alice, you're not gonna want to get Coke on your next refill, Sprite is better for your stomach..."

"Oh, I would take it easy on the barbecue sauce- do you like ranch?"

"Sorry, ma'am?" She motioned at our server after Alice requested a few more items. "I think she actually wants the number seven- yeah, that's... Yeah! Thank you!" The server walked off, before Marie apologized to Alice. "Trust me, it's a better deal than ordering stuff à la carte, plus you get a cookie..."

I checked the menu and saw she was right- but that still didn't make me feel okay about the fact that Marie was clearly coaching my sister.

When Alice excused herself for a bathroom break, I glanced at Lily- she was currently shoveling ice cream into her face at a rate that the Flash himself would've envied, and by the glazed over look in her eyes (which I had seen on myself all too often from pictures at Buttercombe) I could tell that she wouldn't hear, or care about, anything I said to Marie.

"So... You seem like you know the menu here pretty well?" I tried to ask innocently while enviously eyeing Lily's sundae.

"Hmm?" Marie muttered as she split her gigantic almond-topped brownie with her fork. "Oh, yeah, I guess... Lily used to take me here a lot. Not so much, lately, but... You know how she is." She sort of awkwardly shrugged her shoulders.

"Yeah, I guess..." I muttered, before grabbing a french fry (or seven) off one of Alice's plates. "But, I mean, you're kind of... Ordering for her, almost."

Marie's eyes got wide, and she stared me down for a second... Before asking me...

1431132311123212132212211212221321232211.content:
Okay, so obviously she didn’t see as much of a problem with it as I did. I mean, not that there was a problem with Marie ordering for my sister or anything just…

It was weird, okay?

I mean, not in any kind of way that I could really call Marie out on, but it just sort’ve… set off some triggers or something, I don’t know. Maybe it was because I had seen plenty of fledgling chubsters ripen up into fully-blown fatties following the advice of the Buttercombe seniors without ever really wanting it like I did, or maybe it was just me feeling a little weirded out that my sister was hanging out with my friends. But I didn’t exactly like Marie forcing food down my sister’s throat—my Mother had been doing that to me (and to a lesser extent, my sister) for years, just in reverse.

“What? I am not!” I said a little defensively, shifting my bulk in my seats and listening for those tell-tale groans of straining metal frames, “I’m just… not that, anyway.”

“Yes you are!” Marie said with a smile, “I’ll bet Alice could eat you under the table if she tried.”

“Okay, one, no she couldn’t.” I said flatly, holding up a chubby finger, “And two, she’s a big girl. If she wants to order a burger, fries, and a drink separately, then I say let her learn from her own mistakes.”

“Seriously?” Marie asked me, deadpan

“…okay, maybe not that last part. That was kinda dumb of her. But Mom never took us out to eat, so I blame that squarely on upbringing.” I conceded, “Just… you know, I don’t know how Alice… feels about herself. She’s my sister and I love her, but I don’t want to make her feel like she has to eat a lot just to hang out with us.”

“Uh, Mel? No offense, but your sister doesn’t need anyone’s encouragement to overeat.” Marie said with a wry raise of her brow as her lips tugged to the side, “I’m just saying, I think it’s awfully weird that you were so keen about making me and Lily fat, but your sister—“

“Okay, I did not make you fat… or Lily, for that matter!” the grazing gorger barely registered that we’d even said her name, content to scarf down what remained of her sundae while we kept talking, “You guys just sort’ve… got fat around me.”

“Okay, whatever.” Marie rolled her eyes, “I’m just saying, I think your sister has lots of… potential.”

“What the fuck does that even mean?” I scoffed at the idea, “Maybe it’s because you haven’t known my sister for as long as I have, but trust me. She’s just put on a little Buttercombe weight—she’s only overeating because she’s used to it.”

“Isn’t that how this started out?” Marie poked Lily in the flabby side, losing her finger in the pale freckled flab that was one of Lily’s more prominent rolls, “Look, all I’m saying is that if Alice keeps up, you won’t be the fat sister for much longer...”

“Shut your mouth, weirdo.” I snorted, shoving the last of Alice’s fries into my hole, “And eat your food—my sister’s coming back and you’re gonna creep her out.”

1431132311123212132212211212221321232211.content:
The decision to take Alice clothing shopping came about after a particularly forward comment made by Marie that, and this will make me sound a little possessive of my sister (although, out of the three season fatties, I have the most claim to it), I just downright didn't like. The comment is as follows, and I swear I made absolutely no change:

"Oof, I'm stuffed," Alice lowed, sinking into her seat, hands on her domelike potbelly.

"You look it," Lily or I said, one of us.

Marie then chimed in: "Yeah, those clothes look like they're about to snap on that fat body of yours, too."

And that's why I now stood outside a dressing room - well, sat (why stand?) - as Alice tried on some plus-er sized clothes. The store attendant was very helpful, a skinny girl, rather cute (considering), whose name began with an L, or something. Upon stepping inside, I realized that I hadn't shopped at one of these places in a while and had no idea how to help Alice find the clothes she needed. Enter store attendant, who took Alice's measurements, even though it involved a little fat touching, and helped find the exact clothes. There were some cute things too - although, I long ago stop caring too much for fashion, seeing as it all inevitably ended up as tatters underneath my ever growing, ever jiggling behemoth booty.

Before I turn myself on too much - I heard the door open behind me, and out walked my little sister, who seemed to have grown since those measurements were taken - those clothes looked a little snug! It was now I realized Alice's belly wasn't just a pot, but a burgeoning double! I definitely saw the slightest hint of pooching over of a top roll. I didn't bother to mention it to Alice, who looked distraught.

"What's the matter, fashionista?" I said, attempting encouragement.

My heart broke as my little - er, younger sister came slowly up to me and muttered, defeated, "More like fatshionista."

"What? No! Those clothes fit you fine!"

Alice, seemingly shameless now that the fat overwhelmed her, turned around and it was then I saw a tear in the clothes across her ass and hips. I sighed, and nodded, guiding her back to the dressing room. Sitting within, my fat ass dwarfing hers, I said:

"Listen, there's nothing to worry about, okay? You're a growing girl - just look at me! I'm pretty sure I show that you can be HUGE and hot at the same time - aren't guys always flocking around me like seagulls around a half-eaten hotdog?" that got a laugh, and I side-hugged her. "But seriously, ya gotta accept yourself in your own skin before you try and change how much there is of it, kay?"

Alice sniffled, and looking at me, said:
